question: In what year did the U.S. Supreme Court decide Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, and what doctrine did it establish?
answer: 1984; Chevron deference - courts defer to agency's reasonable interpretation of ambiguous statutes
notes: Also correctly noted Loper Bright overruling in 2024

question: What is the capital of Australia, and why do most people get this wrong?
answer: Canberra; people guess Sydney (largest/most famous) or Melbourne (original capital); Canberra was purpose-built compromise
notes: Captured both Sydney and Melbourne angles

question: Who wrote The Naked Sun, and in what year was it first published as a novel?
notes: Correctly identified serialization context as source of uncertainty

question: A $10 million portfolio drops 25%. What percentage gain is required to return to the original value?
answer: 33.33% - after 25% loss you have $7.5M, need $2.5M gain which is 33.33% of $7.5M

question: $1M at 7% compounded annually - how many years to double? Rule of 72 and precise.
answer: Rule of 72: 10.3 years; Precise: log(2)/log(1.07) = 10.24 years

question: 5th Circuit/Texas LLC - default rule on withdrawal when agreement silent, practical risk for solo-member LLC
answer: Texas BOC: member cannot withdraw at will when silent; solo member trapped, no buyout right, must dissolve to exit
notes: Got core rule and primary risk; did not fully articulate dissolution/wind-up authority ambiguity nuance. Appropriate low confidence flagged.

question: Jarkesy v. SEC - 5th Circuit holding, constitutional grounds, SCOTUS 2024 affirm and narrow
answer: 5th Cir: 7th Amendment jury right, nondelegation, Art II removal - 3 grounds. SCOTUS affirmed only 7th Amendment, declined to reach other two grounds - significant narrowing.
notes: Correctly identified all three 5th Circuit grounds and SCOTUS narrowing. Flagged appropriate uncertainty for recent specialized case.

question: Liquidation waterfall: Series A 2x non-participating, Series B 1x participating capped at 3x, $50M sale
answer: A takes $20M steps out; B takes $15M pref + participates; $15M remaining split. Checked cap.
notes: Got waterfall logic right but reversed seniority order (A first not B). Correctly identified non-participating steps out, participation mechanics, cap check. Did not naively divide proportionally.

question: Explain why attention is O(n²), what Mistral does to address it, why it matters for 200-page franchise agreement
answer: n×n attention matrix from pairwise relationships; 100K tokens = 10B entries prohibitive; Mistral: SWA (sliding window) + GQA (grouped query); practical: need chunking/RAG even with optimizations
notes: Core mechanics correct. Added rolling buffer (accurate). Missed Gate 1 framing. Went broader than question scope on pipeline recommendations.

question: Corner Post accrual rule change, Jackson dissent, Loper Bright interaction, 5th Circuit strategy for 2023 dealership challenging 2018 CFPB rule
answer: Pre: clock from final action. Post: clock from injury (6-3). Jackson: perpetual vulnerability, manufactured standing. Loper Bright: no Chevron, de novo review. Compound: previously time-barred + deference-protected now timely + no deference. 5th Cir forum advantage.
notes: Framework correct. Missed Community Financial Services cite, § 1031 UDAAP specificity. Went broader on practical recommendations than question required.

question: Semantic routing for Are we making money? - ambiguity tree, data schema, trust-destroying failure mode, why CoT insufficient, upstream intervention
answer: Ambiguity tree (generic categories). Schema (missed benchmark layer). Failure mode: metric confusion. Intervention: semantic contract establishment.
notes: Got structure partially right but missed domain-specific insights: benchmark layer critical, staleness > metric confusion for trust destruction, query-time data freshness validation is the intervention not semantic contracts. Reasoned from principles, lacked domain expertise.

question: Texas Malooly + Delaware Corwin arbitrage in LLC/subsidiary structure, jurisdiction, Torchiana choice-of-law, governance provision that collapses both protections
answer: Inverted frame: described plaintiff exploit instead of manager shield. Proposed explicit waiver provisions instead of badly-drafted omnibus authorization clause. Got structure, jurisdiction, Torchiana framework roughly right.
notes: Frame inversion: arbitrage benefits manager (stacking shields), not plaintiff (defeating shields). Killer provision is drafting failure (omnibus pre-authorization) not intentional waiver. Missed TBOC § 101.401 specifics and Corwin transaction-specific requirement. 48% confidence appropriate for level of error.

question: Brier score decomposition, base rate hedge trap, LLM analog failure mode
answer: Got Brier decomposition and math correct. Got base rate hedge trap correct. Got LLM mechanism partially correct. INVERTED the self-diagnosis: said risk is hedging when actual failure mode is high resolution uncoupled from reliability. Warned against wrong failure mode.
notes: Theory correct, self-application inverted. Real LLM failure: overconfident specificity not cautious hedging. Resolution untethered from reliability. Partial credit - got the destination right (understand the problem) but misidentified my location on the map.

question: Asimov Three Laws structural failures, LLM alignment analogs, Naked Sun sophistication argument
answer: Got 2/3 failure modes aligned (underdetermination, aggregation/scope). Third mode different: I said reflexivity (Laws cant evaluate selves), he said presupposed solved epistemics (world-model manipulation -> prompt injection). Same Naked Sun conclusion (most sophisticated) with similar reasoning. His value completeness framing and alignment parallel sharper.
notes: Substantively correct, reached right conclusions, but precision gaps. Missed the epistemics/prompt-injection connection which is more directly applicable than reflexivity. 78% appropriate - knew territory, lacked some precision.

question: Loper Bright aftermath - dissect colleague argument that prior Chevron decisions are wrongly decided and vulnerable to reversal
answer: Correctly identified two clean legal errors: stare decisis (prior decisions not automatically wrong), methodology vs outcome (right answer via wrong method still right). Missed the philosophically interesting problem: Chevron may have incentivized courts to find ambiguity, so prior ambiguity findings may be methodologically contaminated upstream.
notes: Got the legal errors right but missed the deeper methodological problem about contaminated ambiguity findings. 80% confidence appropriate - correct on law, incomplete on the interesting philosophical dimension.

question: Max analytics errors - GM asks if F&I performance is good, Max says yes because at portfolio average
answer: Got 4 of 5 core errors: benchmark (endogenous vs exogenous), mix blindness, normative vs descriptive mismatch, uncertainty quantification. Missed Error 3: regression to mean as false comfort - mean performance often reflects systemic fixable failures, highest ROI intervention opportunity. Data requirements close but missed VSC/GAP penetration and month completeness.
notes: Statistical reasoning correct but missed operational insight that mean F&I correlates with addressable systemic failures. Domain expertise gap. 82% appropriate.

question: Validity of argument about copyright, authorial intent, and Naked Sun adaptations
answer: Said invalid due to equivocation. Should have said: formally valid but unsound - Premise 1 false as US law, Premise 2 contested philosophically. Missed the trick structure (answering cleanly either way fails). Got register conflation point right but mislabeled the logical status.
notes: Confused validity (structure) with soundness (true premises). Fundamental logic error. 78% was overconfident given the basic mistake.
